sentences: Marilyn Cotlow (born January 10, 1924) is an American lyric coloratura soprano best remembered for creating the role of Lucy in Gian Carlo Menotti's The Telephone in both the original Broadway and West End productions.

She sang professionally during the 1940s and 1950s in the United States and Europe, performing with such companies as the Metropolitan Opera, Theater Bremen, Theater Basel, and the Wexford Festival Opera.

After 1957, Cotlow mainly retired from performance to devote time to teaching voice and being a mother; although she continued to perform periodically in recitals, on the stage, and on disc up into the 1990s.

After 1957, Cotlow mainly retired from performance to devote time to teaching voice and being a mother; although she continued to perform periodically in recitals, on the stage, and on disc up into the 1990s.
Marilyn Rose Cotlow was born in Minneapolis, Minnesota, on January 10, 1924, to Sander and Bernice Cotlow.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: Marilyn developed a love of classical music and opera by spending hours listening to his large collection of classical music recordings.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: Cotlow's father moved the family of five to Los Angeles in 1936 during the Great Depression in an effort to find work as an attorney.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: She began vocal studies with operatic tenor Hans Clemens in Los Angeles in 1939; studying with him until she relocated to New York six years later.
section: == Early life and education ==

section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: She graduated from Glendale High School in 1942.
section: == Early life and education ==

sentences: Cotlow made her professional opera debut on June 26, 1942 with the California Opera Academy as the Queen of the Night in Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's The Magic Flute.
section: == Early performance career ==

sentences: In March 1946 Cotlow performed as a soloist with the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra under conductor Dmitri Mitropoulos.

sentences: The following summer she performed the role of Blondchen in Mozart's The Abduction from the Seraglio Central City Opera (CCO) with Eleanor Steber, Felix Knight, and Jerome Hines.
section: == Early performance career ==

sentences: She returned to the CCO in the summer of 1948 to perform as Despina in Mozart's Così fan tutte in a production staged by Herbert Graf with sets by Donald Oenslager.

sentences: She performed that same role on tour with the Charles L. Wagner Opera Company with baritone Andrew Gainey as Almaviva in 1948.

sentences: In May 1948 Cotlow and tenor Frank Guarrera were selected as the two winners of the Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air.

sentences: Cotlow was also engaged to perform on The Bell Telephone Hour on NBC Radio after this competition win.
section: == Metropolitan Opera and later performance career ==

sentences: She made her Met debut on December 4, 1948 under the baton of Wilfrid Pelletier as Philine in Mignon; a performance which was broadcast on the Metropolitan Opera radio broadcasts.
section: == Metropolitan Opera and later performance career ==

sentences: Cotlow toured to Los Angeles with the Met's production of Mignon for performances at the Shrine Auditorium in March 1949.
section: == Metropolitan Opera and later performance career ==

sentences: She sang only one other role at the Met during her career: Adina in Donizetti's L'Elisir d'Amore in January 1949 with Giuseppe Di Stefano as Nemorino, Giuseppe Valdengo as Belcore, Italo Tajo as Dr. Dulcamara, Paula Lenchner as Giannetta, and Giuseppe Antonicelli conducting.

sentences: She performed the role of Amina in La Sonnambula at the Wexford Festival Opera in October and November 1954.

sentences: In 1955 she gave a concert tour in the Netherlands.

sentences: In 1956 she performed a concert of opera arias and duets with tenor Brian Sullivan and the Chicago Symphony Orchestra (CSO) under conductor Alfredo Antonini.

sentences: In 1957 she performed a program of opera excerpts from works by Offenbach with the CSO under Julius Rudel with bass Joshua Hecht.

sentences: After the mid 1950s, Cotlow performed rarely as her time became increasingly devoted to raising her children and teaching.

sentences: In 1962 she performed the role of Rosalinde in Die Fledermaus at the theatre of the Detroit Institute of Arts with the Detroit Opera Theatre.

sentences: In 1979 she starred in the world premiere of Thomas Czerny-Hydzik's The Tell-Tale Heart; an opera adaptation of the 1843 short story by Edgar Allan Poe.

sentences: On August 9, 1948 Cotlow married violinist Eugene Altschuler who was concertmaster of the New Orleans Symphony at the time of their marriage.
section: == Teaching career and personal life ==

sentences: Cotlow stated that her opera career was cut short in the mid 1950s because of her decision to return to the United States with her husband.
section: == Teaching career and personal life ==

sentences: From 1972-1981 Altschuler was concertmaster of the Syracuse Symphony Orchestra, after which he served as assistant concertmaster with the Cleveland Orchestra and taught on the faculty of the Cleveland Institute of Music.
section: == Teaching career and personal life ==

sentences: Altschuler died in 2000.
section: == Teaching career and personal life ==

sentences: In the late 1950s Cotlow took up teaching as her performance appearances became rare.
section: == Teaching career and personal life ==

sentences: She has taught voice privately out of her home in Falls Church, Virginia for many years and has also taught voice on the faculties of the University of Michigan, the Peabody Conservatory, and Catholic University of America.
